natural problem: Enrico makes a list of the first twenty positive multiples of 3. Marie makes a list of the first ten positive multiples of 6. How many of the numbers on Marie's list are also on Enrico's list?
natural solution: Enrico's list includes all the multiples of 3 from $1 \cdot 3 = 3$ through $20 \cdot 3 = 60$. Marie's list includes all the multiples of 6 from $1 \cdot 6 = 6$ through $10 \cdot 6 = 60$. Since 6 is a multiple of 3, any multiple of 6 is also a multiple of 3.
All of the numbers on Marie's list are multiples of 3 within the range of Enrico's list, so all $\boxed{10}$ numbers on Marie's list are also on Enrico's list.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes EnricoList MarieList :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "EnricoList = {n. n \<in> {1..20} \<and> 3 dvd n}"
and h1 : "MarieList = {n. n \<in> {1..10} \<and> 6 dvd n}"
shows  "card (EnricoList \<inter> MarieList) = 10"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Enrico makes a list of the first twenty positive multiples of 3. Marie makes a list of the first ten positive multiples of 6. How many of the numbers on Marie's list are also on Enrico's list? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 Enrico's list includes all the multiples of 3 from $1 \cdot 3 = 3$ through $20 \cdot 3 = 60$. Marie's list includes all the multiples of 6 from $1 \cdot 6 = 6$ through $10 \cdot 6 = 60$. Since 6 is a multiple of 3, any multiple of 6 is also a multiple of 3.
 All of the numbers on Marie's list are multiples of 3 within the range of Enrico's list, so all $\boxed{10}$ numbers on Marie's list are also on Enrico's list.
 *)

theorem
fixes EnricoList MarieList :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "EnricoList = {n. n \<in> {1..20} \<and> 3 dvd n}"
and h1 : "MarieList = {n. n \<in> {1..10} \<and> 6 dvd n}"
shows  "card (EnricoList \<inter> MarieList) = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Enrico made a list of all numbers from 1 to 20 that are divisible by 3. Marie made a list of all numbers from 1 to 10 that are divisible by 6. How many numbers are common to both lists? The final answer is 10.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes EnricoList MarieList :: "int list"
assumes h0 : "EnricoList = [3 * i | i <- [1..20]]"
and h1 : "MarieList = [6 * j | j <- [1..10]]"
shows  "length [x <- MarieList. x in set EnricoList] = 10"
a_1.formal solution:

 All of the numbers on Marie's list are multiples of 3 within the range of Enrico's list, so all $\boxed{10}$ numbers on Marie's list are also on Enrico's list.
 *)

fixes EnricoList MarieList :: "int list"
assumes h0 : "EnricoList = [3 * i | i <- [1..20]]"
and h1 : "MarieList = [6 * j | j <- [1..10]]"
shows  "length [x <- MarieList. x in set EnricoList] = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Enrico creates a list of the first 20 multiples of 3. Marie creates a list of the first 10 multiples of 6. How many numbers in Marie's list are also in Enrico's list? The final answer is 10.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes enrico_list marie_list :: "int list"
assumes h0 : "enrico_list = [i * 3. i \<leftarrow> [1..20]]"
and h1 : "marie_list = [i * 6. i \<leftarrow> [1..10]]"
shows  "length (filter (\<lambda>x. x \<in> set marie_list) enrico_list) = 10"

 *)

fixes enrico_list marie_list :: "int list"
assumes h0 : "enrico_list = [i * 3. i \<leftarrow> [1..20]]"
and h1 : "marie_list = [i * 6. i \<leftarrow> [1..10]]"
shows  "length (filter (\<lambda>x. x \<in> set marie_list) enrico_list) = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

Marie's list contains numbers that are less than or equal to 10 and divisible by 6. How many numbers do both lists have in common? The final answer is 10.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Enrico Marie :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..20}. Enrico n = 3 * n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..10}. Marie n = 6 * n"
shows  "card {n. n \<in> {1..10} \<and> Marie n \<in> range Enrico} = 10"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Enrico makes a list of the first twenty positive multiples of 3. Marie makes a list of the first ten positive multiples of 6. How many of the numbers on Marie's list are also on Enrico's list? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 Enrico's list includes all the multiples of 3 from $1 \cdot 3 = 3$ through $20 \cdot 3 = 60$. Marie's list includes all the multiples of 6 from $1 \cdot 6 = 6$ through $10 \cdot 6 = 60$. Since 6 is a multiple of 3, any multiple of 6 is also a multiple of 3.
 All of the numbers on Marie's list are multiples of 3 within the range of Enrico's list, so all $\boxed{10}$ numbers on Marie's list are also on Enrico's list.
 *)

theorem
fixes Enrico Marie :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..20}. Enrico n = 3 * n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..10}. Marie n = 6 * n"
shows  "card {n. n \<in> {1..10} \<and> Marie n \<in> range Enrico} = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Enrico and Marie are both counting numbers in their own unique ways. Enrico counts by multiplying each number from 1 to 20 by 3. Marie, on the other hand, counts by multiplying each number from 1 to 10 by 6. How many numbers from 1 to 10 does Marie count that are also counted by Enrico? The final answer is 10.

fixes Enrico Marie :: "int list"
assumes h0 : "Enrico = [3*n | n <- [1..20]]"
and h1 : "Marie = [6*m | m <- [1..10]]"
shows  "length (filter (\<lambda>x. x `elem` Enrico) Marie) = 10"

 *)
